Fresh Killings In Liberia Fresh Killings In Liberia

At least 48 Liberians including women and children were killed in fighting in a Monrovia suburb yesterday, according to a correspondent who counted the bodies after they were brought to the city centre. The bodies, many of them burnt and dismembered, were buried in a mass grave near the city centre late in the afternoon. The commander of the West African peacekeeping force (ECOMOC), General John Inienger, told a press conference that the Paynesville area where the fighting took place had been brought back under control. Fighting involving Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front (NPFL) forces broke out there late Wednesday. Inienger blamed the fighting, the worst in the Liberian capital for over two years, on "NPFL fighters and their collaborators." Witnesses said the shooting stopped around 4:00 p.m. local time. Inienger said the attack was "co-ordinated with some groups within Monrovia with the intention of causing chaos and disorder within the city," and investigations were being carried out to establish who was behind it. "We are not going to fold our arms and watch while the situation is made to deteriorate deliberately," he said. OIC Talks Tough On Bosnia OIC Talks Tough On Bosnia

Moslem leaders yesterday forged a united stand on Bosnia, calling for more UN peacekeepers and increased NATO air strikes to halt attacking Serb forces. The Organisation of the Islamic Conference (OIC) summit also ended with an appeal to its 51 member states including the PLO to provide between 300,000 dollars and five million dollars in financial and humanitarian aid for Bosnian Moslems. It agreed on a non-binding code of conduct aimed at preventing OIC states from financing or supporting Islamic militant groups. But it was left divided after King Hussain on Wednesday walked out angrily over the rejection of a proposal commending) ordan's role as caretaker of the Jerusalem holy sites, an Arab official said. Bosnian President Alija Izetbegovic attended the summit as an observer and gave a speech appealing for support for his beleaguered republic. The final document on Bosnia called for the 23,000-strong UN Protection Force to be increased and reinforced with heavy artillery. Nasreen Receives Priz Amid Protests Nasreen Receives Priz Amid Protests

Threatened Bangladeshi writer, Taslima Nasreen, was awarded a literary prize by the European parliament yesterday amid protests from French intellectuals who claim her plight has been exaggerated. Thirty-two-year-old Nasreen, wholives in exile in Sweden after fleeing a death threatfor alleged blasphemy in Bangladesh, was given the parliament's Sakharov prize as the intellectuals protested what they termed excessive media exploitation of her visit to France last month. Speaker Klaus Haensch, a German social democrat, handed the prize 10 Nasreen, who was visibly moved. Of the Russian scientist Andrei Sakharov after whom the prize is named, Nasreen said in a thank-you speech: "I feel a strong affinity with him because of his refusal to be a pawn in political power games." She added: "If we allow violence and terror to grow unchecked, then one day we shall have a planet of barbarism where might is right." Meanwhile, writer and profession polemicist Jean-Edem Hallier made "solemnprotest" yesterday and said the award was a "stain" on the parliament. Hallier on Wednesday denounced what he called "the Nasreen mystifica- tion" and said her book, "Lajja" (Shame) - which tells a story of Moslem persecution of Hindus - was "a fake novel, a fake document with false information which has notbeen confirmed in Amnesty International reports. Medical Professor Alexandre Minskowski, a frequent visitor to Bangladesh on aid missions, said media treatment of the Nasreen case was "irresponsible" and the harm done to Bangladesh is "criminal."
